chunks.original_text: 故物损於彼者盈於此，成於此者亏於彼。 所谓川竭谷虚，丘夷渊实也。 损盈成亏，随世随死。 此世亦宜言生。 往来相接，间不可省，畴觉之哉？ 成者方自谓成，而已亏矣； 生者方自谓生，潜已死矣。 范曰：丘夷而渊实，则损於彼者未必不盈於此； 栽成而木毁，则成於此者未有不亏於彼。 损己而益，成己而坏，生死相循於无涯之变，往来相转於不停之机，日夜无隙，间不容栉，非大明终始者，畴觉所以然哉？ 凡一气不顿进，一形不顿亏，亦不觉其成，亦不觉其亏。 皆在冥中而潜化，固非耳目之所瞻察。 范曰：消者，俄且息气，固不顿进也； 盈者俄且虚形，固不顿亏也。 其进也，日造所无而好所新； 其亏也，日减所有而损所成。 虽欲执之而留，皆自冥冥中去矣。 《庄子》壑泽之喻，必日夜半有力者负之而去，盖明乎此。 亦如人自世音生至老，貌色智态，亡日不异； 皮肤爪发，随世随落，非婴孩时有停而不易也。 形色发肤，有之粗者，新故相换，犹不可识，况妙於此者乎？ 间不可觉，俟至后知。 卢曰：夫心识潜运，阴阳鼓作，故形体改换，天地密移，损益盈虚，谁能觉悟？ 所以贵夫道者，知本而不忧亡也。 政和：神也者，妙万物而为言者也。 妙不可识，则凡丽於形，拘於数，囿於天地之间者，二气之运转无已，万物之往来不穷。 求其主张推行是者而不可得，又乌足以知之哉？ 唯圣人通乎物之所造，觉此而冥焉。 彼俟至后知，盖亦后觉之莫觉者矣。 范曰：人生天地间，一受其成形，不亡以待尽，其形化，其心与之。 然若骤若驰，莫觉莫悟，讵能不失赤子之心乎？ 古之体道者，以神御形，化化而不化於化，四肢百体，将为尘垢。 死生亦大矣，而不得与之变。 虽万化而未始有极，何足以息心已？ 故含德之厚，复於婴儿，上与造物者游，下与外生死，齐终始者为友。 杞国有人忧天地崩坠，身亡所寄，废寝食者。 又有忧彼之所忧者，因往晓之， 彼之所忧者惑矣，而复以不惑忧彼之所惑，不忧彼之所忧，喻积惑弥深，何能相喻也哉。 曰：天，积气耳。 亡处亡气。 若屈伸呼吸，终日在天中行止，奈何忧崩坠乎？ 夫天之苍苍，非铿然之质； 则所谓天者，岂但远而无所极邪？ 自地而上，则皆天矣。 故俯仰喘息，未始离天也。 其人曰：天果积气，日月星宿不当坠邪7 晓之者曰：日月星宿，亦积气中之有光耀者， 气亦何所不胜，虽天地之大，犹自安於太虚之域，况乃气相举者也。 只使坠，亦不能有所中伤。 其人曰：奈地坏何？ 晓者曰：地，积块耳，充塞四虚，亡处亡块。 若躇步跐蹈，终日在地上行止，奈何忧其坏？ 其人舍然大喜。 舍，宜作释，此书释字作舍晓之者亦舍然大喜。 此二人一以必败为忧，一以必全为喜，此未知所以为忧喜也。 而互相慰喻，使自解释，固未免於大惑也。 卢曰：天为积气，何处无气也？ 地为积块，何处无块也？ 块无所隐，气无所崩，日月是气中有光者，汝何忧於崩坠乎？ 范曰：确然而上者，天其运乎。 是直积气耳，无为而清者耶。 不然，将恐裂。 颓然而下者，地其处乎。 是直积块耳，无为而宁者耶。 不然，将恐发。 昆仑磅礴，立碍於太虚之间，忧其坏者亦已惑矣，忧彼之所忧者其惑滋甚。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, what is diminished there is filled here; what is completed here is depleted there. This is what is meant by rivers running dry and valleys emptying, hills leveling and abysses filling. Loss and fullness, completion and depletion follow the world and follow death—yet this world may also be called life. Coming and going connect without interruption, with no gap to spare—who can perceive it? One who has just achieved completion is already depleted; one who has just attained life is already secretly dead.

Fan said: When hills level and abysses fill, what is diminished there is not necessarily unfilled here. When a tree is planted and grows, what is completed here is not without depletion there. To diminish oneself is to benefit; to complete oneself is to ruin. Life and death cycle through boundless transformation; coming and going revolve through ceaseless mechanism. Day and night proceed without pause, with no interval to comb through—unless one is profoundly enlightened to the beginning and end, who can perceive the reason for this?

For qi does not advance all at once, nor does form deplete all at once. One does not sense its completion, nor does one sense its depletion. All occurs in obscurity and transforms in secret, inherently beyond the reach of ears and eyes.

Fan said: What dissipates soon breathes its last, yet does not advance all at once. What fills soon empties its form, yet does not deplete all at once. In its advance, it daily creates what was not and delights in what is new. In its depletion, it daily reduces what was and diminishes what was completed. Though one may grasp and try to retain it, it departs from obscurity. As *Zhuangzi*’s metaphor of valleys and marshes says: "At midnight, a forceful one carries them away"—this clarifies the point.

It is like a person from birth to old age: appearance, complexion, wisdom, and demeanor change without a day’s pause. Skin, nails, and hair fall away with the world, not remaining as they were in infancy. Even the coarse aspects of form and appearance—new and old replacing each other—are unrecognizable, let alone what is subtler than this? The interval is imperceptible; one must wait until later to know.

Lu said: The mind’s subtle operation, yin and yang’s dynamic interplay—thus the body transforms, heaven and earth shift imperceptibly. Loss and gain, fullness and depletion—who can awaken to it? This is why the Dao is prized: to know the root and not grieve over loss.

*Zhenghe* states: The spirit is that which subtly governs the myriad things. If its subtlety is unknowable, then all that is bound to form, constrained by number, or confined between heaven and earth—where the revolving of the two qi never ceases and the coming and going of the myriad things never ends—cannot be grasped in its governing and unfolding. How then can one know it? Only the sage, penetrating to the source of things, awakens to this and merges with it. Those who wait until later to know are the last to awaken, if they awaken at all.

Fan said: Born between heaven and earth, once one receives one’s completed form, it does not perish until it is exhausted. The form transforms, and the mind transforms with it. Yet it rushes and gallops, unperceiving and unawakened—how can one not lose the heart of an infant? The ancients who embodied the Dao used spirit to guide form, transforming without being transformed by transformation. The four limbs and hundred parts would become dust and grime. Death and life are great indeed, yet one does not change with them. Though myriad transformations have no end, how can this weary the heart? Thus, one of profound virtue returns to the state of an infant, roaming above with the Creator and below with those who transcend life and death, equalizing beginning and end as friends.

A man of the state of Qi worried that heaven and earth would collapse and he would have no place to dwell, forsaking sleep and food. Another, worried about his worry, went to enlighten him. The first man’s worry was deluded, yet the second, though not deluded, worried about his delusion—refusing to worry about what he worried about—only deepened the confusion. How could they enlighten each other?

He said: Heaven is but accumulated qi. There is no place without qi. Like bending and stretching, breathing in and out, one moves and rests within heaven all day—why worry about collapse? The azure of heaven is not a solid substance. Then what is called heaven—is it merely distant and without limit? From the earth upward, all is heaven. Thus, looking up and down, breathing—one never departs from heaven.

The man said: If heaven is accumulated qi, should not the sun, moon, and stars fall? The enlightener said: The sun, moon, and stars are luminous within accumulated qi. Qi is all-pervading—even the vastness of heaven and earth rests securely within the realm of the Great Void, let alone what is lifted by qi. Even if they fell, they could cause no harm.

The man said: What of the earth’s ruin? The enlightener said: The earth is but accumulated clods, filling the four directions. There is no place without clods. Like stepping and treading, one moves and rests upon the earth all day—why worry about its ruin? The man released his concern and rejoiced greatly. (Note: *she* should be *shi* [释], meaning "release." The enlightener, too, released his concern and rejoiced greatly.)

These two—one worrying about inevitable ruin, the other rejoicing in inevitable preservation—did not know the true cause of worry and joy. Though they consoled and enlightened each other, they remained deeply deluded.

Lu said: Heaven is accumulated qi—where is there no qi? Earth is accumulated clods—where is there no clod? Clods hide nothing; qi collapses nowhere. The sun, moon, and stars are luminous within qi—why worry about collapse?

Fan said: What stands firm and rises is heaven in motion—is it merely accumulated qi, naturally clear? If not, it might tear apart. What sinks and settles is earth in stillness—is it merely accumulated clods, naturally at peace? If not, it might erupt. Kunlun’s vastness stands as an obstruction in the Great Void. To worry about its ruin is delusion; to worry about another’s worry is even greater delusion.

chunks.original_text: 以不惑是尚大不惑。 长庐子闻而笑之曰：虹蜺也，云雾也，风雨也，四时也，此积气之成乎天者也； 山岳也，河海也，金石也，火木也，此积形之成乎地者也。 知积气也，知积块也，奚谓不坏？ 夫混然未判，则天地一气，万物一形。 分而为天地，散而为万物。 此盖离合之殊异，形气之虚实。 夫天地，空中之一细物，有中之最巨者。 难终难穷，此固然矣； 难测难识，此固然矣。 忧其坏者，诚为大远； 言其不坏者，亦为未是。 天地不得不坏，则会归於坏。 遇其坏时，奚为不忧哉？ 此知有始之必终，有形之必坏，而不识休戚与阴阳升降，器质与天地显没也。 卢曰：积气积块，以成天地，有积有成，安得无坏耶？ 但体大难终，不可则见。 若遇其坏时，何得不忧？ 范曰：经曰：焉知天地之丧，不有大於天地者乎？ 则即空中以观，是为细物。 又曰，天地者，形之大也。 则即有中以观，是为最巨，以其难终，故难穷，以其难测，故难识。 忧其坏者，既为大远； 言其不坏者，亦为未是。 然复谓天地不得不坏，遇其坏时奚为不忧？ 则长庐子之言由在可笑之域。 子列子闻而笑曰：言天地坏者亦谬，言天地不坏者亦谬，坏与不坏，吾所不能知也。 虽然，彼一也，此一也。 彼一谓不坏者也，此一谓坏者也，若其不坏，则与人偕全； 若其坏也，则与人偕亡。 何为欣戚於其间哉？ 故生不知死，死不知生； 来不知去，去不知来。 坏与不坏，吾何容心哉？ 生之不知死，犹死之不知生。 故当其成也，莫知其毁，及其毁也，亦何知其成？ 此去来之见验，成败之明征，而我皆即之，情无彼此，何处容其心乎？ 卢曰：夫天地者，物之大者也。 形体者，物之细者也。 大者亦一物也，细者亦一物也，有物必坏，何用辩之哉？ 且人生不知死，死不知生，来去不自知，成坏不能了，近取诸已且未能知，亦何须用心於天地而忧辩於物外耶？ 政和：自器言之，有成又有坏； 自道言之，无成无坏。 囿於器者，谓其有形有气，不得不坏； 通於道者，知其不陷不坠，莫得而坏。 惟达者知通乎此。 此列子所以无容心於其间也。 范曰：天地之在空中，譬犹一沤之在水也。 水自为涯，沤亦成水，其坏亦水，成已俄坏，坏已俄成。 杞人之忧其坏，是犹悲人之丧者也。 有忧彼之所忧者，故能晓之，是犹悲人之悲者也。 长庐子闻而笑之，是犹悲夫悲人之悲者也。 进而上之，坏与不坏，无所容心，是为至极之论。 然则生死之变，去来之机，皆不足以相知也。 坏与不坏，曾何欣戚於其间哉？ 舜问乎烝曰：道可得而有乎？ 舜欲明群有皆同於无，故举道以为发问之端也。 曰：汝身非汝有也，汝何得有夫道。 郭象曰：夫身者非汝所能有也，块然而自有耳。 有非所有，况於无哉？ 卢曰：夫汝我者，自他形称耳，非谓神明也。 俗以己身为我，前人为汝，欲有其道，安可得乎？ 故曰汝身非汝有，安得有夫道。 舜曰：吾身非吾有，孰有之哉？ 据有此身，故重发问。 曰：是天地之委形也。 是一气之偏后者也。 生非汝有，是天地之委和也。 积和故成生耳。 性命非汝有，是天地之委顺也。 积顺故有存亡耳。 郭象曰：若身是汝有，则美恶死生，当制之由汝。 今气聚而生，汝不能禁也；
chunks.translated_text:
To be free from delusion is to aspire to the greatest freedom from delusion.

Changluzi heard this and laughed, saying: The rainbow, the clouds and mist, the wind and rain, the four seasons—these are the accumulations of qi that form heaven. The mountains and peaks, the rivers and seas, metal and stone, fire and wood—these are the accumulations of form that constitute earth. To know that qi accumulates and that clods accumulate—how can one then speak of indestructibility? Before the primordial chaos divided, heaven and earth were one qi, and the myriad things were one form. When they separated into heaven and earth and dispersed into the myriad things, this was merely a difference of convergence and divergence, of emptiness and fullness in form and qi. Now, heaven and earth are but a tiny thing within the void, the greatest entity within what has form. That they are difficult to exhaust, difficult to fathom—this is certainly so. That they are difficult to measure, difficult to comprehend—this is certainly so. To worry about their ruin is indeed far-fetched; to claim they will not be ruined is also incorrect. Heaven and earth cannot but be ruined, and when they meet their ruin, they will return to it. When that time comes, how can one not be anxious? This is to know that what has a beginning must have an end, that what has form must be destroyed, yet not to recognize the vicissitudes of fortune and the rise and fall of yin and yang, nor the emergence and disappearance of vessels and heaven and earth.

Lu said: Qi and clods accumulate to form heaven and earth—where there is accumulation and formation, how can there be no ruin? Only because their vastness makes their end difficult to witness. Yet if one encounters their time of ruin, how can one not be anxious?

Fan said: The classic states: How do we know that the demise of heaven and earth does not give rise to something greater than heaven and earth? Viewed from within the void, they are but a tiny thing. It also states: Heaven and earth are the greatest of forms. Viewed from within what has form, they are the most immense. Because their end is difficult to exhaust, they are difficult to fathom; because they are difficult to measure, they are difficult to comprehend. To worry about their ruin is indeed far-fetched; to claim they will not be ruined is also incorrect. Yet to say that heaven and earth cannot but be ruined, and that when their time of ruin comes one should not be anxious—this places Changluzi’s words squarely in the realm of the laughable.

Master Liezi heard this and laughed, saying: To say that heaven and earth will be ruined is mistaken; to say they will not be ruined is also mistaken. Whether they are ruined or not, I cannot know. Nevertheless, that is one perspective, and this is another. That perspective speaks of indestructibility; this one speaks of ruin. If they are not ruined, they endure together with humanity; if they are ruined, they perish together with humanity. Why rejoice or grieve over this? Thus, the living do not know death, and the dead do not know life; the coming does not know the going, and the going does not know the coming. Whether ruined or not, why should I concern myself with it? Not knowing life while alive is like not knowing death while dead. When something comes into being, none know its destruction; when it is destroyed, how can one know its formation? This is the visible proof of going and coming, the clear evidence of success and failure. I accept them all—my feelings hold no distinction between them. Where is there room for concern?

Lu said: Heaven and earth are the greatest of things; the physical body is the smallest of things. The great are but one thing, and the small are but one thing. All things must be ruined—what is the use of debating it? Moreover, in life one does not know death, and in death one does not know life; coming and going are not self-aware, and formation and ruin cannot be understood. If one cannot even comprehend what is close at hand, why expend the mind on heaven and earth and worry over debates beyond the realm of things?

Zhenghe said: From the perspective of vessels, there is formation and there is ruin; from the perspective of the Dao, there is neither formation nor ruin. Those confined to vessels say that because things have form and qi, they cannot but be ruined. Those who comprehend the Dao know that they neither collapse nor fall, and thus cannot be ruined. Only the enlightened understand this passage. This is why Master Liezi has no room for concern.

Fan said: Heaven and earth within the void are like a bubble in water. Water forms its own boundary, and the bubble becomes water; when it is ruined, it is still water. It forms and is ruined in an instant, ruined and forms in an instant. The worry of the man of Qi over its ruin is like mourning the death of a person. Those who worry about what others worry about can enlighten them—this is like mourning the mourning of others. Changluzi’s laughter is like mourning those who mourn the mourning of others. Advancing further, whether ruined or not, there is no room for concern—this is the ultimate discourse. Thus, the transformations of life and death, the mechanisms of coming and going, are not sufficient to be known. Whether ruined or not, why rejoice or grieve over it?

Shun asked Zheng: Can the Dao be possessed?

Shun wished to clarify that all beings are identical to nothingness, so he took the Dao as the starting point for his question.

Zheng replied: Your body is not your own—how can you possess the Dao?

Guo Xiang said: The body is not something you can possess; it simply exists of itself. If you do not even possess what you have, how much less can you possess what you do not have?

Lu said: You and I are merely designations for self and other in form; they do not refer to the spirit. The common people take their own bodies as "I" and others as "you." How can one hope to possess the Dao? Thus it is said: Your body is not your own—how can you possess the Dao?

Shun said: If my body is not my own, then who possesses it?

He pressed the question further, based on the possession of this body.

Zheng replied: It is the entrusted form of heaven and earth, a partial manifestation of the one qi. Life is not your possession—it is the entrusted harmony of heaven and earth. Only through the accumulation of harmony does life come to be. Fate is not your possession—it is the entrusted compliance of heaven and earth. Only through the accumulation of compliance do existence and perishing come to be.

Guo Xiang said: If the body were yours to possess, then beauty and ugliness, life and death, would be determined by you. Yet qi gathers and life arises, and you cannot prevent it.

Fan said: What stands firm and rises is heaven in motion—is it merely accumulated qi, naturally clear? If not, it might tear apart. To worry about its ruin is delusion; to worry about another’s worry is even greater delusion.

chunks.original_text: 气散而死，汝不能止也。 明其委结而自成，非汝之有也。 孙子非汝有，是天地之委蜕也。 气自委结而蝉蜕耳。 若是汝有，则男女多少亦当由汝也。 故行不知所往，处不知所持，食不知所以。 皆在自尔中来，非知而为之也。 天地强阳，气也。 又胡可得而有邪？ 天地即复委结中之最大者也。 今行处食息，皆强阳之所运动，岂识其所以然？ 强阳，犹刚实也。 而非刚实理之至，反之虚和之极，则无形无生，不死不终，则性命何所委顺？ 子孙何所委蜕？ 行处何所止泊？ 饮食何所因假者也？ 卢曰：既不知神明之为道也，故假天地以言之。 天主神用，地主形物。 涉有者，委形也。 体和者，生性也。 应用者，委顺也。 情育者，委蜕也。 汝今行止食息，但知强阳之所运，而不知神明之真宰也。 亦可得有夫道者耶？ 或曰：虞、舜，圣人也，安得不知道乎？ 答曰：夫假宾主辩惑岂可玄默而已耶？ 然《庄子》曰：上梁倚有圣人之才而无圣人之道，我有圣人之道而无圣人之才。 是知有济物之才，君居极之位者，未必能知道。 处山林之下，有独善之名者，未必能理人。
chunks.translated_text:
When qi scatters, death comes, and you cannot halt it. Clearly, its gathering and dissolution arise of themselves—it is not yours to possess. Your descendants are not yours to possess—they are the entrusted shedding of heaven and earth, the cicada’s molt as qi gathers and disperses of itself. If they were yours to possess, then even the number of sons and daughters would be determined by you. Thus, in walking you know not where you go; in dwelling you know not what you hold; in eating you know not why. All emerges from the self-so, not from knowing or doing.

Heaven and earth are the supreme yang—qi itself. How then could they be possessed? Heaven and earth are but the greatest of all entrusted gatherings. Now, in walking, dwelling, eating, and resting, all are set in motion by the supreme yang—how could you know the reason? Supreme yang is like unyielding solidity, yet it is not the ultimate principle of unyielding solidity. When turned toward the extreme of emptiness and harmony, there is no form, no life, no death, no end. Then to what would fate and life be entrusted in compliance? To what would descendants be entrusted in shedding? Where would walking and dwelling find their mooring? On what would eating and drinking depend?

Lu said: Since the numinous clarity of the Way is unknown, one borrows heaven and earth to speak of it. Heaven governs the numinous function; earth governs forms and things. That which enters into being is the entrusted form. That which embodies harmony is the life of nature. That which responds and functions is the entrusted compliance. That which nurtures emotions is the entrusted shedding. Now, in your walking, stopping, eating, and resting, you know only the movement of the supreme yang, yet remain unaware of the true lord of numinous clarity. How then could you possess the Dao?

Someone asked: Yu and Shun were sages—how could they not know the Dao?

The answer: When borrowing guest and host to dispel confusion, how could one remain in silent mystery alone? Yet *Zhuangzi* says: "The ruler of Liang possesses a sage’s talent but not a sage’s Dao; I possess a sage’s Dao but not a sage’s talent." Thus, one who has the talent to aid the world and occupies the highest position may not necessarily know the Dao. One who dwells in the mountains and forests with a reputation for solitary integrity may not necessarily govern others.

chunks.original_text: 是故黄帝即位三十年，然后梦华胥之国； 放勋见乎四子，然后窅然汾水之阳。 舜之未寤，亦何足怪之？ 政和：虚则亡，实则有，凡得而有者，皆可执而取之。 道妙无形，深不可识。 既莫得而有，而人之一身，形体性命，方该而存，倏化而亡，亦安能有？ 形者，体也，故以身为天地之委形。 和者，气也，故以生为天地之委和。 物之生也，顺性命之理而已，故以性命为天地之委顺。 身也者，父母之遗体也，故以孙子为天地之委蜕。 若然者，亦非我有也。 故行不知所往，处不知所持，食不知所味。 既有制之者矣。 亦有使之者矣，直天地强阳，气之所运动而已。 又安能有夫道？ 虽然，道者，人之所共由也。 故曰道将为汝居，是岂终不可得而有耶？ 盖认而有之则莫能有，唯圣人有之以不有耳。 范曰：道本无物，汝身亦虚，虚而非有，道将孰寄？ 故观天下之物，汝之所得擅者，莫若乎身； 身之所存者，莫若乎生； 其生之本者，莫若乎性命也； 其身之所亲者，莫若乎孙子也。 汝皆不得而有之，故观汝之身，知本无知，则行安知所往，处安知所持，食安知所味，是皆天地强阳，气之所为耳。 所谓道者，汝安得而有耶？ 齐之国氏大富，宋之向氏大贫。 自宋之齐，请其术。 国氏告之曰：吾善为盗。 始吾为盗也，一年而给，二年而足，三年大壤。 自此以往，施及州闾。 向氏大喜，喻其为盗之言，而不喻其为盗之道，遂踰垣凿室，手目所及，亡不探也。 未及时，以脏获罪，没其先居之财。 向氏以国氏之谬己也，往而怨之。 国氏曰：若为盗若何？ 向氏言其状。 国氏曰：嘻，若失为盗之道至此乎？ 今将告若矣。 吾闻天有时，地有利。 谓春秋冬夏，方土出所有也。 吾盗天地之时利，云雨之滂润，山泽之产育，以生吾禾，殖吾稼，筑吾垣，建吾舍。 陆盗禽兽，水盗鱼鳖，亡非盗也。 夫禾稼、土木、禽兽、鱼鳖，皆天之所生，岂吾之所有？ 天尚不能自生，岂能生物？ 人尚不能自有，岂能有物？ 此乃明其自生自有者也。 然吾盗天而亡殃。 天亡其施，我公其心，何往而有怨哉。 夫金玉珍宝，谷帛财货，人之所聚，岂天之所与？ 天尚不能与，岂人所能聚？ 此亦明其自能自聚。 若盗之而获罪，孰怨哉？ 人有其财，我犯其私，所以致咎。 卢曰：夫天地不仁，以万物为刍狗。 既无情於生育，岂有心於取与哉？ 小大相吞，智愚相役，因时以兴利，力制以徇私，动用取与，皆为盗也。 人财则不尔主守，以自供取之获罪，此复怨谁也。 范曰：盗有羡志，取非其有。 然有所谓公盗者，有所谓私盗者，禾稼、土木、禽兽、鱼鳖，天之所生，国氏盗之而亡殃； 金玉、珍宝、谷帛货财，人之所聚，向氏盗之而获罪。 二者不同，非其有而取之则一也。 向氏大惑，以为国氏之重罔己也，遇东郭先生问焉。 东郭先生曰：若一身庸非盗乎？ 盗阴阳之和以成若生，载若形，况外物而非盗哉？ 若其有盗耶，则我身即天地之一物，不得不私有之； 若其无盗耶，则外内不得异也。 诚然，天地万物不相离也，仞而有之，皆惑也。 夫天地，万物之都称； 万物，天地之别名。 虽复各私其身，理不相离，仞而有之心之，惑也。 因此而言，夫天地委形，非我有也，饰爱色貌，矜伐智能，己为惑矣。

Thus, after thirty years on the throne, the Yellow Emperor dreamed of the Land of Huaxu; only after Yao met the Four Masters did he gaze in wonder upon the southern banks of the Fen River. How then could it be strange that Shun had not yet awakened?

In *Zhenghe* it is said: Emptiness is loss, fullness is possession—whatever is grasped and held is subject to being seized. The Dao’s subtlety is formless, its depth unknowable. Since it cannot be possessed, how then can the human body—with its form, nature, and life—claim to endure when it arises and vanishes in an instant?

The body is but a vessel, and thus one’s person is Heaven and Earth’s entrusted form. Harmony is qi, and thus life is Heaven and Earth’s entrusted harmony. The birth of things follows the principle of nature and life, and thus nature and life are Heaven and Earth’s entrusted compliance. The body is the legacy of one’s parents, and thus descendants are Heaven and Earth’s entrusted shedding. If this is so, then none of it is truly one’s own. Thus, in walking one knows not where one goes, in dwelling one knows not what one holds, in eating one knows not the taste. There is indeed one who governs this, one who commands it—nothing more than the supreme yang of Heaven and Earth, the movement of qi alone. How then could one possess the Dao?

Yet the Dao is the shared path of all people. Thus it is said: “The Dao will make a dwelling for you.” Could it then remain forever unpossessable? To claim possession is to lose it; only the sage possesses it by not possessing.

Master Fan said: The Dao is originally without substance, and your body is also empty. If emptiness is not possession, where then could the Dao reside? Thus, of all things under Heaven, what you claim to possess most exclusively is your own body; of all that abides within the body, nothing is more precious than life; of the root of life, nothing is more fundamental than nature and destiny; of all that is closest to the body, nothing is dearer than one’s descendants. Yet you cannot truly possess any of these. Therefore, observing your own body, you see that it is fundamentally without knowledge: in walking, how could you know where you go? In dwelling, how could you know what you hold? In eating, how could you know the taste? All is but the supreme yang of Heaven and Earth, the workings of qi. How then could you claim to possess the Dao?

In Qi, the Guo family was immensely wealthy; in Song, the Xiang family was desperately poor. Traveling from Song to Qi, Xiang sought their method. Guo told him: “I am skilled in theft.” When I first began stealing, I had enough after one year, sufficiency after two, and great abundance after three. From then on, my bounty extended to towns and villages. Overjoyed, Xiang grasped the words of theft but not the Dao of theft. He scaled walls, broke through chambers, and seized whatever his hands and eyes reached. Before long, he was caught with stolen goods and forfeited his ancestral wealth. Believing Guo had deceived him, Xiang went to complain. Guo said: “How did you steal?” Xiang described what he had done. Guo said: “Alas! Have you lost the Dao of theft to this extent? Now I will tell you.

I have heard that Heaven has its seasons, Earth its advantages. Spring, autumn, winter, summer—each region yields what it produces. I steal Heaven and Earth’s timely benefits, the soaking rains of clouds, the nurturing bounty of mountains and marshes, to grow my grain, cultivate my crops, build my walls, and construct my dwellings. On land, I steal from birds and beasts; in water, I steal from fish and turtles—nothing is not stolen. Yet grain, crops, trees, birds, beasts, fish, and turtles are all born of Heaven. How could they be mine? Heaven cannot even produce itself—how could it produce things? People cannot even possess themselves—how could they possess things? This is to make clear that all things arise and possess themselves.

Yet when I steal from Heaven, I incur no misfortune. Heaven does not withhold its gifts, and I act with impartiality—where then could resentment arise? Gold, jade, treasures, grain, silk, and wealth are what people amass. How could they be Heaven’s to give? If Heaven cannot give them, how can people amass them? This too makes clear that all things gather themselves. If you steal them and incur punishment, whom should you resent?

People possess their wealth, and I violate their private holdings—this is why you bring trouble upon yourself.”

Master Lu said: Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat the myriad things as straw dogs. Devoid of feeling in their nurturing, how could they have intent in giving or taking? The great consume the small, the clever exploit the foolish. Seizing opportunities to pursue profit, using force to serve private ends, all actions of taking and giving are theft. Yet when people hoard wealth, they do not act as its true masters. To take from them and be punished—whom else could you resent?

Master Fan said: Theft arises from covetous ambition, taking what is not one’s own. Yet there is what is called public theft and what is called private theft. Grain, crops, trees, birds, beasts, fish, and turtles are born of Heaven—Guo stole from them and incurred no misfortune. Gold, jade, treasures, grain, silk, and wealth are amassed by people—Xiang stole from them and was punished. Though the two differ, to take what is not one’s own is the same.

Bewildered, Xiang believed Guo had gravely deceived him. He encountered Master Dongguo and asked him about it. Master Dongguo said: “Is not your very body itself theft? You steal the harmony of yin and yang to form your life, to bear your form—how much more are external things not theft? If theft exists, then my body is but one thing among Heaven and Earth’s myriad things, and I cannot but claim it as my own. If theft does not exist, then inner and outer cannot differ. Truly, Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things are inseparable. To measure and claim possession is delusion.

Heaven and Earth are the collective name of the myriad things; the myriad things are the alternate name of Heaven and Earth. Though each claims its own body, in principle they are not separate. To measure and claim possession is delusion. Thus, Heaven and Earth’s entrusted form is not mine. To adorn and cherish appearances, to boast and flaunt wisdom and ability—this is delusion.”

chunks.original_text: 至於甚者，横仞外物以为己有，乃标名氏以自异，倚亲族以自固，整章服以耀物，藉名位以动众，封殖财货，树立权党，终身欣玩，莫由自悟。 故《老子》曰：吾所以有大患者，为吾有身。 《庄子》曰：百骸六藏，吾谁与为亲？ 领斯旨也，则方寸与本虚齐空，形骸与万物俱有也。 范曰：窃有小大皆迷者也。 向氏喻其为盗之言，而不喻其为盗之道，故失之於殉货； 国氏喻其为盗之道，而不喻其所以为盗之道，故失之於累物。 苟得乎道，则内之一身，不可横私也。 况於外物之纷纷乎？ 何则？ 且人之生也，百骸、九窍、六藏，该而存焉。 吾谁与为亲？ 认而有之，是为大惑。 惟能不以利累形，不以形累心，则视万物与我将择焉而不可得，及吾无身吾有何患？ 国氏之盗，公道也，故亡殃； 若之盗，私心也，故得罪。 公者对私之名，无私则公名灭矣。 今以犯天者为公，犯人者为私，於理未至。 卢曰：天地无私、取之无对，故无殃也。 人心有私，取之有情，故为盗也。 以有私之心取有私之物，私则有对，得罪何疑？ 故法者，禁人之私，无对无禁也。 有公私者，亦盗也； 直所犯之异耳，未为非盗。 亡公私者，亦盗也。 一身不得不有，财物不得不聚，复欲遣之，非能即而无心者也。 卢曰：圣人设法教化，不害人，不侵众者，皆非盗也。 不违法者，则为公道； 违於法者，则为私道焉。 虽不违於公而封於己者，亦为盗也，况违法封己乎。 公公私私，天地之德。 生即天地之一理，身即天地之一物。 今所爱吝，复是爱吝天地之间生身耳，事无公私，理无爱吝者也。 知天地之德者，孰为盗耶？ 孰为不盗耶？ 天地之德何耶？ 自然而已。 何所历其公私之名？ 公私之名既废，盗与不盗，理无差也。 卢曰：知公知私而无私焉。 与物同例而不怪者，是天地之德也。 若知天地之德，取而无私心者，是不欺乎天。 取之不殊於众人，得之无私，不为盗。 若然者，谁为盗耶？ 谁为不盗耶？ 唯了神悟道者知之矣。 政和：取非其有，无非盗也。 或以公道而无殃，或以私心而得罪，时在夫不累於有与认而有之之问耳。 然有公私者，未能无羡，故曰有公私者，亦盗也； 而无公私者，亦未能勿忘，故曰亡公私者，亦盗也。 公公私私，任其自然，而无容心焉。 则兼怀万物，是谓天地之德。 知夫此者，泯然大同。 虽参差不齐，而与天地为合。 吾乌能知其辩哉？ 故天瑞之篇终焉。 范曰：自营为私，背私为公，公本无名，因私而得。 天任理则大而公，故国氏盗天之所生则为公道，人任情则小而私，故向氏盗人之有则为私心。 自道观之，皆在一曲。 有公私者，亦盗，无公私者亦盗，公公私私，天地之德。 圣人两不废焉。 觉此而冥，则盗与不盗，乌能知其辩？ 冲虚至德真经四解卷之三竟 冲虚至德真经四解卷之四

As for those who go to extremes, they arbitrarily measure and claim external things as their own, even inscribing names to set themselves apart, relying on kin to secure their position, adorning their robes to dazzle others, leveraging rank and status to sway the masses, amassing wealth and property, and establishing factions of power—all their lives they delight in such playthings, never awakening to the truth. Thus *Laozi* says: “The reason I have great trouble is that I have a body.” *Zhuangzi* says: “Of my hundred bones and six viscera, with whom shall I be intimate?” Grasping this principle, the mind’s square inch is as empty as the primordial void, and the bodily form exists equally among the myriad things.

Fan says: “To claim possession, whether great or small, is delusion.” Xiang’s parable speaks of theft in word but not of the Dao of theft, thus erring in pursuing wealth. Guo’s parable speaks of the Dao of theft but not of the reason for theft, thus erring in being burdened by things. If one attains the Dao, even the body within cannot be arbitrarily claimed as one’s own—how much less the myriad external things? Why? When a person is born, their hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera all exist together. With whom shall I be intimate? To recognize and claim them is great delusion. Only by not allowing profit to burden the form, nor the form to burden the mind, can one see that the myriad things and the self cannot be distinguished—when I have no self, what trouble can I have?

Guo’s theft is the public Dao, thus incurring no misfortune; Xiang’s theft is private desire, thus incurring guilt. “Public” is the opposite of “private”; without private desire, the name “public” vanishes. Now to call violating Heaven “public” and violating man “private” is not the ultimate principle. Lu says: “Heaven and Earth are without private desire; to take from them is without opposition, thus incurring no misfortune. The human heart has private desire; to take with attachment is theft. To take what is privately desired with a heart of private desire—private desire has its opposite, so how can guilt be doubted?” Thus, the law forbids private desire; without opposition, there is no prohibition. Those who act with public or private intent are still thieves—only the object of violation differs, not the nature of theft. Those who transcend public and private are also thieves. The body cannot but exist, and wealth cannot but be gathered; to then seek to abandon them is not the same as being without attachment from the outset.

Lu says: “The sage establishes laws and teachings, harming none and encroaching not upon the multitude—this is not theft. Those who do not violate the law act by the public Dao; those who violate the law act by the private Dao. Even if one does not violate the public but claims things for oneself, it is still theft—how much more so to violate the law and claim for oneself?” Public and private are the virtues of Heaven and Earth. Life is one principle of Heaven and Earth; the body is one thing among Heaven and Earth’s myriad things. What one now covets and clings to is but coveting and clinging to the life and body born between Heaven and Earth. In affairs, there is no public or private; in principle, there is no coveting or clinging. One who knows the virtue of Heaven and Earth—who is a thief? Who is not a thief? What is the virtue of Heaven and Earth? It is simply spontaneity. Where does it pass through the names of public and private? Once the names of public and private are abolished, theft and non-theft are without distinction in principle.

Lu says: “To know public and private yet be without private desire, to be of the same pattern as things without finding it strange—this is the virtue of Heaven and Earth. If one knows the virtue of Heaven and Earth and takes without private desire, this is not deceiving Heaven. To take without differing from others, to obtain without private desire, is not theft. If so, who is a thief? Who is not a thief? Only those who thoroughly comprehend the spirit and awaken to the Dao know this.”

*Zhenghe* says: “To take what is not one’s own is nothing but theft. Some act by the public Dao and incur no misfortune; others act by private desire and incur guilt—the difference lies in whether one is burdened by possession or by recognizing and claiming possession. Yet those who act with public or private intent cannot be without attachment, thus it is said: those with public or private intent are also thieves. Those who transcend public and private cannot be without lingering attachment, thus it is said: those who have transcended public and private are also thieves. To act with public or private intent as it arises naturally, without contrivance—this is to embrace the myriad things, which is called the virtue of Heaven and Earth. One who knows this merges into great unity. Though things differ in shape and form, they unite with Heaven and Earth. How can I discern their distinctions? Thus the chapter *Heavenly Auspices* concludes.”

Fan says: “To act for oneself is private; to turn away from private desire is public. Public originally has no name; it is only through private desire that it is known. When Heaven follows principle, it is vast and public—thus Guo’s theft of what Heaven produces is the public Dao. When man follows emotion, it is petty and private—thus Xiang’s theft of what man possesses is private desire. From the perspective of the Dao, both are partial. Those who act with public or private intent are thieves; those who transcend public and private are also thieves. Public and private are the virtues of Heaven and Earth. The sage does not discard either. Awakening to this and merging into obscurity, how can one discern the distinction between theft and non-theft?”

*The Four Explanations of the* Perfect Virtue of the Pristine Dao, *Volume Three* concludes.

chunks.original_text: 和光散人高守元集 黄帝 禀生之质谓之性，得性之极谓之和，故应理处顺，则所适常通，任情背道，则遇物斯滞。 卢曰：此明忘形养神，从玄默以发真智。 始其养也，则遗万有而内澄心； 发其智则化含生以外，接物。 故其初也，则斋心服形不亲政事； 其末篇也，则赞孔墨以济人焉。 此其大旨。 政和，古之明大道者，先明天而道德次之《列子》以天瑞首篇，而继之以《黄帝》岂谓是欤。 范曰：即无物之自虚者，随处皆通； 执有物之为实者，触途生碍。 然则有而为之其易耶？ 必将泯是非利害之心，去智巧果敢之烈，猜虑不萌，俾物无得，而伤吾宗不出，俾人无得而先，崇自贤之行，持常胜之道，子以袭诸人间，则人道之患庶几其息矣。 华胥之国，姑射之山，夫岂远哉？ 此一篇之旨也。

The *Harmonious Radiance Scattered One*, Gao Shouyuan, compiled:

What the Yellow Emperor received at birth is called *nature*; attaining the utmost of nature is called *harmony*. Thus, responding to principle and dwelling in compliance, one’s path is ever unobstructed; following emotion and turning from the Dao, one encounters things and is impeded.

Lu says: This clarifies forgetting form to nurture spirit, following profound silence to manifest true wisdom. At the outset of nurturing, one relinquishes the myriad existences to inwardly clarify the heart-mind; when wisdom is manifested, one transforms all living beings outwardly to engage with things. Thus, in its beginning, one purifies the heart-mind and disciplines the body, not mingling in governance; in its final chapter, one praises Confucius and Mozi to aid humanity. Such is its great purport.

In governance and harmony, those of old who illuminated the great Dao first clarified Heaven, then followed with virtue and the Dao. *Liezi* begins with *Heavenly Omens* and is followed by *The Yellow Emperor*—could this be the reason?

Fan says: The self-emptiness of the non-substantial flows unimpeded everywhere; clinging to the substantiality of things, one meets obstacles at every turn. Then is it easier to act from having? One must dissolve the heart-mind of right and wrong, gain and loss, abandon the fervor of cunning and decisiveness, uproot suspicion and anxiety, so that things cannot harm one’s essence, nor can others precede one. Rejecting the conduct of self-aggrandizement and upholding the constant Dao of victory, if you apply this among men, the afflictions of the human realm may well cease. The Land of Huaxu, the Mountain of Guye—are they far away? Such is the purport of this chapter.

chunks.original_text: 黄帝即位十有五年，喜天下戴己，随世而喜耳。 养正命，正当为性。 娱耳目，供鼻口，焦然肌色皯黣，昏然五情爽惑。 役心智未足以养性命，祇足以焦形也。 卢曰：举代之人，咸以声色、饮食养其身，唯丰厚者，则为富贵矣。 而圣人知此道足以伤生，故焦然不乐也。 第一篇知神为生主，第二篇欲明道以养身，故先示众人之所溺，然后渐次而进之。 又十有五年，忧天下之不治，随世而忧耳。 竭聪明，进智力，营百姓，焦然肌色皯黣，昏然五情爽惑。 用聪明未足以政治，秖足以乱神也。 卢曰：代谓之君子，理人之士也。 皆劳心苦己，以身徇物，以求其名，以向其利耳。 而不知役神以丧实，去道斯远矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Emperor Huangdi, having reigned fifteen years, rejoiced that all under heaven bore him allegiance—yet this was but worldly joy. He cultivated the mandate of correctness, which is precisely the cultivation of one’s nature. He delighted the ears and eyes, gratified the nose and mouth, yet his complexion withered and darkened, his five emotions grew dull and confused. The toil of heart and wit was insufficient to nurture his nature and life—it only sufficed to wither his form.

Lu says: The people of his age all sought to nourish their bodies with sounds and sights, with food and drink; only those of abundant means were deemed noble and wealthy. Yet the sage knew this path was enough to harm life, and so he grew withered and joyless.

The first chapter reveals the spirit as the master of life; the second seeks to clarify the Dao for nurturing the body. Thus it first shows what the multitude drowns in, then gradually guides them forward.

After another fifteen years, he grew anxious that all under heaven remained untended—yet this was but worldly anxiety. He exhausted his keen hearing and bright vision, advanced his wit and strength, and busied himself for the hundred clans. Again his complexion withered and darkened, his five emotions grew dull and confused. The use of keen hearing and bright vision was insufficient for governance—it only sufficed to disorder the spirit.

Lu says: Those of his age called themselves "noble men," scholars who ordered others. All wearied their hearts and wore themselves out, sacrificing their bodies for things, seeking fame and pursuing profit. Yet they knew not that toil of the spirit forfeits reality, and thus they drifted ever farther from the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 黄帝乃喟然赞曰：赞当作叹。 朕之过淫矣。 淫当作深。 养一己其患如此，治万物其患如此。 惟任而不养，纵而不治，则性命自全，天下自安也。 卢曰：淫者，失於其道也。 含生之物，咸知养己，自私以为生，不知所生生而之死也； 操仁义者，咸知徇名以取利，自私以为能，亦不知所以丧神伤生而知死也。 徇己自私以为小人，济物无私代以为君子。 善之以恶约外则有殊，求名丧实约内则俱失。 方明大道，故双非之也。 范曰：鼓舞万物而不与圣人同忧者，道也。 吉凶与民同患者，事也。 体道则无忧，涉事则有患，圣人不得已而临莅天下，亦乌至而恝然耶？ 内而养一己，则养正命，娱耳目，供口鼻，其患既如此。 外而治万物，竭聪明，进智力，营百姓，其患又如此。 是岂胥易技系劳形怵心，固若是其多忧耶？ 方以百姓心为心； 则人之所畏不得不畏故尔。
chunks.translated_text:
Yellow Emperor then sighed in admiration—*sighed* should read *lamented*. "My errors run deep indeed—*deep* should read *excessive*. To nurture the self alone brings such calamity; to govern the myriad things brings such calamity. Only by entrusting without nurturing, by indulging without governing, may one’s nature and life remain whole, and all under heaven rest in peace."

Lu says: *Excessive* means straying from the Dao. All living things know to nurture themselves, selfishly preserving their lives, yet they know not that what gives life also leads to death. Those who grasp at benevolence and righteousness all know to pursue fame for profit, selfishly believing themselves capable, yet they know not how this exhausts the spirit, harms life, and hastens death. To serve the self and act selfishly is the way of the petty man; to aid others without selfishness is the way of the noble man. Outwardly, goodness and evil appear distinct, yet inwardly, the pursuit of fame and loss of reality both end in ruin. Now that the great Dao is made clear, both are condemned.

Fan says: To animate the myriad things without sharing the sage’s anxieties—this is the Dao. To share the people’s fortunes in good and ill—this is worldly affairs. Embracing the Dao, one knows no sorrow; engaging in affairs, one meets with calamity. The sage governs all under heaven only when unavoidable—how could he do so with indifference? Inwardly nurturing the self means preserving the true mandate, delighting the ears and eyes, sating the mouth and nose—yet its calamities are already thus. Outwardly governing the myriad things means exhausting keen hearing and bright vision, advancing wit and strength, and busying oneself for the hundred clans—its calamities are again thus. How could such trivial skills, which bind the body and startle the heart, inherently entail such manifold sorrows? Only when one takes the people’s heart as one’s own heart must one also share what they fear.

chunks.original_text: 於是放万机，舍宫寝，去直侍； 彻钟悬，减厨膳，退而闲居大庭之绾，斋心服形，心无欲，则形自服。 三月不亲政事。 卢曰：放万机者，非谓都无所行也。 事至而应，如四时焉。 故曰天何言哉？ 四时行焉，百物生焉。 不劳焦思以邀虚名，不想能於千载欲垂芳於竹帛耳。 但冥冥然应用，不得已而运之，不封崇其身名，不增加其嗜欲，不丰厚其滋味，不放肆於淫声。 斋肃其心，退伏其体。 三月者，一时也。 孔子曰：颜回三月不违仁是也。 择贤才而责成赏罚无私焉，是不亲政事也。 昼寝而梦， 将明至理不可以情求，故寄之於梦。 圣人无梦也。 游於华胥氏之国。 政和：至人不以物累形，不以形累心，上与造物者游，下与外生死、无终始者为友。 忧喜无变於己，亦有何患？ 黄帝以此去万有之累，而将复乎一。 故斋心服形，梦游华胥氏之国也。 范曰：圣人之治，一日二日万几，今曰放万几，则不劳心於土苴之末矣。 舍宫寝，非累於居处之安也； 去直侍，非乐於使令之众也； 彻钟悬，则耳不綦声； 减厨膳，则口不綦味。 退而间居大庭之馆，斋心服形，三月不亲政事，则又洁斋至矣。 故华胥之国於此得而梦进焉。 经曰：形接为事，神遇为梦。 尽之所为，必形於梦，则魂交之寐未必虚也； 夜之所梦，必合於昼，则形开之觉未必实也。 惟通乎昼夜之道，而知者乃能。 融梦觉於一致，等视世间得失、是非、贵贱生死，无非梦幻。 故居化人之宫者，以梦而游； 执尹氏之役者，以梦而乐； 获郑人之鹿者，以梦而讼。 随有所遇而安之者，知所幻而非真也。 何独於此而疑之？ 然古之真人，其寝无梦列子言此，将明至道之不可以情求，姑寄於梦而已。 华胥氏之国在弇州之西，台州之北。 不必便有此国也，明至理之必如此耳。 《淮南》云：正西曰弇州，西北曰台州。 不知斯齐国几千万里，斯，离也。 齐，中也。 盖非舟车足力之所及，神游而已。 舟车足力，形之所资者耳。 神道恍惚，不行而至者也。 范曰：华则敷而离根，胥则出而相见。 理有至妙，不必求之於窈冥昏默之中。 虽离道之根，而与物相见，所谓归根复命者，常自若也。 正西日弇州，正北曰台州，弇州之西，台州之北，则又归根复命之地也。 夫道降中庸，则有足者皆可至於丘。 不知斯齐国几千万里，则去人为远矣，盖非舟车足力之所及，神游而已。 唯神也，不疾而速，不行而至，故出入六合，游乎无有，乌往而不暇哉？ 其国无师长，自然而已。 其民无嗜欲，自然而已。 自然者，不资於外也。 不知乐生，不知恶死，故无夭殇； 不知亲己，不知疏物，故无爱憎； 不知背逆，不知向顺，故无利害； 理无生死，故无所乐恶； 理无爱憎，故无所亲疏，理无逆顺，故无所利害也。 都无所爱惜，都无所畏忌。 入水不溺，入火不热，斫挞无伤痛，指植无痟痒。 至和者无物能伤，热溺痛痒。 实由矜惧，义例详於下章。 痟痒，酸痟也。 义见《周官》。 乘空如履实，寝虚若处床。 云霞不碍其视，雷霆不乱其听，美恶不滑其心，山谷不踬其步，神行而已。 至顺者，无物能逆也。 卢曰：寄言也，斋心服形，神与道合，则至其大国矣。 夫神者，生之主也。 既为生主，则役神以养生。 养之失理，却成於损也。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, he set aside the myriad affairs, forsook the palace chambers, dismissed his attendants; stilled the bells and chimes, reduced the royal fare, and withdrew to dwell in leisure within the Hall of the Great Court. There, he purified his heart and disciplined his form—his heart free of desire, his form naturally compliant. For three months, he did not attend to governance.

Lu said: To set aside the myriad affairs does not mean doing nothing at all. Matters arise and are met as the four seasons turn. Thus it is said: What does Heaven say? The four seasons proceed, the hundred things are born—yet it does not toil in anxious thought to court empty fame, nor scheme for ability across a thousand ages to leave a fragrant name upon bamboo and silk. Rather, it responds in profound obscurity, moved only by necessity, neither exalting its own name nor increasing its cravings, neither enriching its flavors nor indulging in wanton sounds. It purifies the heart and subdues the body. Three months is but one season. Confucius said: Yan Hui did not stray from benevolence for three months—this is the same. Selecting worthy talents and entrusting them with rewards and punishments without partiality—this is not attending to governance oneself.

In daytime repose, he dreamed. Profound truths cannot be sought through emotion, so they are entrusted to dreams. The sage has no dreams. He wandered in the land of Huaxu. In perfect harmony: the perfected one does not burden the form with things, nor burden the heart with the form; above, he roams with the Creator, below, he befriends those beyond life and death, without beginning or end. Sorrow and joy do not alter him—what calamity could there be? The Yellow Emperor, by this means, cast off the burdens of the myriad things and returned to the One. Thus, purifying the heart and disciplining the form, he dreamed of wandering in the land of Huaxu.

Fan said: The governance of the sage, though daily handling ten thousand details, now setting aside the myriad affairs, no longer wearies the heart over the least trifles. Forsaking the palace chambers is not attachment to the comfort of dwelling; dismissing attendants is not delight in the multitude of servants. Stilling the bells and chimes, the ear is not ensnared by sound; reducing the royal fare, the mouth is not ensnared by taste. Withdrawing to dwell in leisure within the Hall of the Great Court, purifying the heart and disciplining the form, for three months not attending to governance—this is the utmost purity of fasting. Thus, the land of Huaxu is attained in dream.

The Classic says: When form meets, it is affairs; when spirit encounters, it is dream. All that one does must manifest in dream—thus the communion of the hun in sleep is not necessarily empty. All that one dreams at night must accord with the day—thus the awakening of the form is not necessarily real. Only one who comprehends the Way of day and night can know this. Merging dream and waking into one, regarding the world’s gains and losses, right and wrong, nobility and baseness, life and death as no more than dream and illusion—thus, dwelling in the palace of the transformed man, one wanders in dream; serving as the steward of Yin, one finds joy in dream; obtaining the deer of the man of Zheng, one litigates in dream. Whatever one encounters, one accepts—knowing it is illusion, not real. Why doubt this alone?

Yet the true person of old, in sleep, had no dreams. Liezi speaks of this to clarify that the utmost Dao cannot be sought through emotion, and so provisionally entrusts it to dream. The land of Huaxu lies west of Yan Prefecture and north of Tai Prefecture. It need not actually exist—it merely illustrates that the utmost principle must be thus. *Huainanzi* says: Due west is Yan Prefecture, northwest is Tai Prefecture. How many thousands of miles distant is this land? *Si* means "apart," *qi* means "center." It is beyond the reach of boats, carriages, or foot—only spirit may roam there. Boats, carriages, and feet are but the resources of form; the spirit’s way is subtle and indistinct, arriving without traveling.

Fan said: *Hua* means "to unfold and depart from the root," *xu* means "to emerge and meet." The principle is supremely subtle, yet need not be sought in the depths of darkness and silence. Though departing from the root of the Dao, it meets with things—this is what is meant by "returning to the root and recovering the mandate," which remains ever thus. Due west is Yan Prefecture, due north is Tai Prefecture; west of Yan and north of Tai is the place of returning to the root and recovering the mandate.

When the Dao descends to the mean, even those with feet may reach the mound. How many thousands of miles distant is this land? It is far removed from humanity—beyond the reach of boats, carriages, or foot, only spirit may roam there. Only spirit—swift without haste, arriving without traveling—thus it enters and exits the six directions, roams in the realm of nothingness. Where could it not go in leisure?

In that land, there are no teachers or leaders—only spontaneity. Its people have no cravings—only spontaneity. Spontaneity does not rely on externals. They do not know joy in life, nor aversion to death—thus no premature deaths; they do not know closeness to self, nor distance from things—thus no love or hatred; they do not know opposition or compliance—thus no benefit or harm. Principle knows no life or death—thus no joy or aversion; principle knows no love or hatred—thus no closeness or distance; principle knows no opposition or compliance—thus no benefit or harm. They cherish nothing, fear nothing. Entering water, they do not drown; entering fire, they do not burn; struck or flogged, they feel no pain; pricked or prodded, they feel no itch. In perfect harmony, nothing can harm them—heat, drowning, pain, or itch. In truth, these arise from anxiety and fear; the principles are detailed in the following chapter. *Xiao yang* means "aching itch," as explained in the *Rites of Zhou*.

They tread the void as if on solid ground, sleep in emptiness as if on a bed. Clouds and mist do not obstruct their sight, thunder and lightning do not disturb their hearing, beauty and ugliness do not confuse their hearts, mountains and valleys do not trip their steps—only spirit moves. In perfect compliance, nothing can oppose them.

Lu said: This is metaphorical speech. Purifying the heart and disciplining the form, when spirit unites with the Dao, one attains that great land. Spirit is the master of life. As the master of life, it governs spirit to nurture life. If nurturing is contrary to principle, it becomes harm instead.

chunks.original_text: 俗以益嗜欲者为养生，适为丧年之本矣。 故君子养於性，小人养於情，养性者，无嗜欲，保自然，不乐生，不恶死，无向背僧爱，无畏忌自然。 神行者，神合於道也。 非是别有一国、别类之人耳。 故曰：仁道不远，行之则至。 一言契者，交臂相得焉。 政和：在弇州之西，台州之北，去齐国几千万里，则其道幽远而无穷。 故惟神游者，所能至也。 无师长而自治，无嗜欲而自足，死生无变於己，亲疏不累其身。 不就利而利亦不至，不违害而害亦不来，都无所爱惜，都无所畏忌，而心有所忘，入水不溺，入火不热，斫挞无伤痛，指擿无痟痒。 而形有所遗，乘空寝虚，不碍不踬，恶往而不暇，以是出入往来阴阳之所，不能测也，而况於人乎？ 故曰神行而已。 范曰：其国无师长，自然而已。 则无出治之劳，而国者自治； 其民无嗜欲，自然而已。 则无贪求之念，而民者自朴。 生不知死，死不知生也，故其出不欣，其入不距，孰为而有夭恶？ 视人如我，视我如人也，故无所甚亲，无所甚疏也。 孰为而有爱憎？ 逆之而怒，顺之而喜也，故不背所异，不向所同孰，为而有利害？ ； 都无所爱憎，故其心无所知，都无所畏忌，故其形无惕。 若然者，大浸稽天而不溺，大旱金石流，土山焦而不热。 虽有勇，刺之不入，虽有力，击之弗中，触实不碍，乘虚不坠。 视不用目而见晓，听不用耳而闻和。 刳心无物，美恶不能汩也。 潜行不窒，山谷不能踬也。 利用出入，往来不穷，是其神之所为乎。 黄帝既寤， 亦寄之眠寤耳，圣人无眠觉也。 怡然自得，召天老、力牧、太山稽，三人，黄帝相也。 告之曰：朕闻居三月，斋心服形，思有以养身治物之道，弗获其术。 身不可养，物不可治，而精思求之未可得。 疲而睡，所梦若此。 今知至道不可以情求矣，朕知之矣，朕得之矣，而不能以告若矣。 不可以情求，则不能以情告矣。 又二十有八年，天下大治，几若华胥氏之国， 政和：劳形怵心，知而辩焉，故其术弗获，斋心服形，觉而冥焉，故其道乃得。 虽有情有信，而无为无形，故至道不可以情求，而知之得之者，亦莫能以告也。 而帝登假。 假当为遐。

The vulgar mistake indulgence in desires for nurturing life, yet this is precisely the root of premature death. Thus the noble person nurtures their nature, while the petty person nurtures their emotions. To nurture one’s nature is to be free of cravings, to preserve the natural, to feel no joy in life nor aversion to death, to hold no preferences or aversions, no fears or taboos—simply following the natural. One whose spirit moves is one whose spirit unites with the Dao. This is not some separate realm or distinct kind of person.

Thus it is said: the Way of humaneness is not distant—practice it and you arrive. A single word in accord, and you grasp it in an instant. *Zhenghe* lies west of Yan Prefecture and north of Tai Prefecture, thousands of miles from the state of Qi—its Way is secluded and boundless. Only those who wander in spirit can reach it. Without teachers or superiors, they govern themselves; without cravings, they are self-sufficient. Life and death bring no change to them, near and far impose no burden on their bodies. They do not pursue profit, yet profit does not come; they do not resist harm, yet harm does not arrive. They cherish nothing, fear nothing, and their hearts forget all things. They enter water yet do not drown, enter fire yet do not burn, suffer blows without pain, endure scratches without itching. Their forms are left behind, they tread the void and sleep in emptiness, unobstructed and untroubled. Wherever they go, they have no leisure—thus they come and go through the realms of yin and yang, beyond all reckoning, let alone human comprehension. This is what is meant by "spirit moving alone."

Fan said: In that land, there are no teachers or superiors—all is natural. Thus there is no labor of governance, yet the state governs itself. Its people have no cravings—all is natural. Thus there are no greedy impulses, and the people remain unspoiled. They do not know life in death, nor death in life, so they feel no joy in departure nor resistance to return. Who then could fear early death? They see others as themselves and themselves as others, so there is nothing too intimate, nothing too distant. Who then could harbor love or hatred? Anger arises from opposition, joy from compliance—so they do not turn away from difference nor incline toward sameness. Who then could be swayed by profit or harm? Free of love and hatred, their hearts know nothing; free of fear and taboo, their forms feel no alarm. Such beings are untouched by the greatest floods, though they reach the heavens; unburned by the fiercest droughts, though metal and stone melt and mountains wither. Though assailed by the brave, blades cannot pierce them; though struck by the strong, blows cannot land. They touch solidity yet are unobstructed, tread emptiness yet do not fall. They see without eyes, hear without ears. Their hearts are hollowed of all things—beauty and ugliness cannot disturb them. They move in concealment yet are not stifled; mountains and valleys cannot trip their steps. Their comings and goings are inexhaustible—such is the work of their spirit.

The Yellow Emperor, having awakened, knew this was but a dream—yet the sage is never truly asleep or awake. Serene and self-content, he summoned Tian Lao, Li Mu, and Tai Shan Ji—his three ministers—and said: "I have heard that after three months of purifying the heart and disciplining the form, one should seek the Way to nurture the self and govern all things, yet I have not attained its method. The self cannot be nurtured, things cannot be governed, and though I have sought it with utmost diligence, I have not found it. Exhausted, I slept, and dreamed thus. Now I know the supreme Dao cannot be sought through emotion. I have understood, I have attained it—but I cannot explain it to you. If it cannot be sought through emotion, then it cannot be conveyed through emotion."

Twenty-eight years later, the realm was greatly ordered, nearly like the land of Hua Xu. *Zhenghe*: Toil of form and agitation of heart, to know and debate—thus the method was not attained. Purification of heart and discipline of form, awakening to the obscure—thus the Way was obtained. Though it has reality and truth, it

chunks.original_text: 百姓号之，二百年余不辍。 卢曰：既寤於道也，自不因外物以得之。 疲而睡者，冥於理，去嗜欲也。 识神归性，不可以情求也。 不能以告若者，心澄忘言也。 凡以数理天下者，但成其空名，数极则迹见，虚而不能实也。 上以虚名责於下，下以虚名应於上，上下相蒙，积虚以为理，欲求纯素，其可得乎？ 夫道者，神契理合，应物以真，非偏善於小能，不暴怒於小过。 如春之布万物皆生，俗易风移，自然而化，不知所以化，不觉所以成。 故百姓思之，不知其极也。 范曰：有身则累物而丧我。 入而内观身，本无身也，必期於养之，则未离於身； 见出而外观物，本无物也，必期於治之，则未离於物。 见物我靡认，其去道也远矣。 何者？ 至道之精，窈窈冥冥； 至道之极，昏昏默默，求之以情，道终弗获。 其所以知之者，无知而已； 其所以得之者，无得而已。 知本无知，得本无得，又乌能以是告人耶？ 审造乎是，则游心於淡，合气於漠，顺物自然，无容私焉，而天下治矣。 千岁厌世，去而上仙，彼且释弓而登假，人则从是也。 孰肯以物为事？ 尝原庄周之书，言黄帝始以仁义撄人心，而继以问道广成，盖以谓绝圣弃智而天下治。 则黄帝其人，所谓撄人心者，是宜寓言耳。 是篇之意正与此合。 列姑射山在海河洲中，见《山海经》山上有神人焉。 凝寂故称神人。 吸风饮露，不食五谷； 既不食谷矣，岂复须吸风饮露哉？ 盖吐纳之貌，不异於物耳。 心如渊泉，形如处女； 尽柔虚之极者，其天姿自粹，非养而不衰也。 不偎不爱， 偎者亦爱也，刍狗万物，恩无所偏。 偎音隐偎。 仙圣为之臣； 仙者，寿考之迹圣者，治世之名。 不畏不怒，愿态为之使； 畏威也。 若此岂有君臣役使之哉？ 尊卑长短，各当其分，因此而寄称耳。 不施不惠，而物自足； 不聚不敛，而已无愆。 愆，蹇乏也。 阴阳常调，日月常明，四时常若，若，顺也。 风雨常均，字育常时，年谷常丰，而土无札伤，人无夭恶，物无疵疠，鬼无灵响焉。 天人合德，阴阳顺序，昏明有度，灾害不生，故道合二仪，契均四时。 《老子》曰：以道莅天下者，其鬼不神。 卢曰：此言神之合道也，故假以方外之中，托以神人之目，不因五谷以为养，吐纳真气以为全，心如澄水无波浪之能鼓形，如处女无思虑之所营。 喜怒不入其襟，是非不干其用，无求无欲，同天地之不仁，不惠不施，正阴阳之生育万物所不能挠，鬼神所不能灵证之真，其功若此也。 政和：神也者，妙万物而为言者也。 体神之妙而出乎形数之外，故能胜物而无累。 吸风饮露，不食五谷，则不志於养； 心如渊泉，形如处女，则静一而不二； 不偎不爱，仙圣为之臣； 不畏不怒，愿悫为之使； 则与道相辅而行。 若然者，从容无为而阴阳和静，群生不伤，故不施不惠，不聚不敛，阴阳调，四时若，字育时，年谷丰，人无夭恶，物无疵疠，鬼无灵响焉。 此圣人所以曲成万物而不遗者也。 范曰：神也者，妙万物而为言者也。 万物在道之末。 体神者，寓乎万物之上，视万物莫足以撄其心者，故能胜物而无累。 然则列姑射之山，非神人，孰能居之？ 吸风饮露，不食五谷，则不志於养也； 心如渊泉，则静尊而不流； 形如处女，则柔顺而无忤；

The people mourned him for over two hundred years without cease.

Lu said: Having awakened to the Dao, one no longer relies on external things to attain it. Exhaustion leading to sleep is obscurity in principle, the abandonment of desires. The spirit of consciousness returns to its nature—this cannot be sought through emotion. That it cannot be conveyed to you is because the heart is stilled and words forgotten. All who govern the world through calculation merely achieve an empty name; when calculation reaches its limit, traces become visible, and what is empty cannot be made real. Those above demand empty names from those below, and those below respond with empty names to those above—superior and inferior deceive one another, accumulating emptiness as governance. How then can one seek purity and simplicity?

The Dao is a spiritual union with principle, responding to things with truth. It does not favor petty virtues nor rage at minor faults. Like spring spreading over all things, giving life, customs transform and winds shift—naturally and imperceptibly, without knowing how transformation occurs or how completion is achieved. Thus the people long for it, unaware of its limits.

Fan said: To have a body is to be burdened by things and lose the self. Turning inward to observe the body, one finds the body fundamentally non-existent; yet if one insists on nurturing it, one has not departed from the body. Looking outward to observe things, one finds things fundamentally non-existent; yet if one insists on governing them, one has not departed from things. Seeing neither self nor other, one drifts far from the Dao. Why? The essence of the supreme Dao is profound and obscure; its ultimate is dim and silent. Sought through emotion, the Dao will never be attained. What enables one to know it is no-knowledge; what enables one to attain it is no-attainment. Knowing is fundamentally no-knowledge; attainment is fundamentally no-attainment—how then could one convey this to others?

Truly understanding this, one roams the heart in blandness, unites qi in vastness, follows the natural course of things, and admits no selfishness—thus the world is ordered. After a thousand years, weary of the world, one departs to become an immortal of the highest realm, releasing the bow and ascending in transcendence. People follow this path—who would still take things as their concern?

I have examined the writings of Zhuang Zhou, who said that the Yellow Emperor first disturbed the human heart with benevolence and righteousness, then later inquired of Guangchengzi about the Dao, suggesting that only by abandoning sagacity and discarding knowledge could the world be ordered. Thus the Yellow Emperor, the so-called disturber of the human heart, must have been speaking in allegory. The meaning of this text aligns precisely with that.

Mount Liegu in the midst of the sea and rivers is recorded in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. Upon it dwells a divine person—serene and still, hence called a divine person. They inhale wind and drink dew, eating no grain; having abandoned grain, why would they still need to inhale wind or drink dew? This describes the appearance of breath cultivation, no different from other things. Their heart is like a deep spring, their form like a maiden—having reached the ultimate of softness and emptiness, their natural endowment is pure, not declining through cultivation. They show no partiality or attachment—partiality is also attachment—treating all things like straw dogs, with no favoritism. Immortals and sages serve as their ministers; immortals are the traces of long life, sages the names of ordered governance. They show no fear or anger, and the sincere and guileless serve them. How could there be any lordship or servitude here? High and low, long and short, each occupies its proper place—this is merely a figurative expression.

They do not bestow favors, yet all things are sufficient; they do not hoard or accumulate, yet nothing is lacking. Yin and yang are always harmonious, sun and moon always bright, the four seasons always in order, winds and rains always balanced, nurturing always timely, grains always abundant. The land knows no pestilence, people no premature death or misfortune, things no blemish or plague, and ghosts no supernatural manifestations. Heaven and humanity unite in virtue, yin and yang follow their sequence, darkness and light observe their measure, and disasters do not arise. Thus the Dao harmonizes the two modes and accords with the four seasons. As *Laozi* says: "Those who govern the world with the Dao—ghosts have no spirit."

Lu said: This speaks of the spirit uniting with the Dao, hence it borrows from the midst of what lies beyond form, designating it as a divine person. It does not rely on grain for nourishment but preserves wholeness through the inhalation and exhalation of true qi. The heart is like still water, incapable of stirring waves in the form; like a maiden, free from the entanglements of thought. Joy and anger do not enter their breast, right and wrong do not interfere with their function. Without seeking or desiring, they align with Heaven and Earth’s non-benevolence; without bestowing or giving, they rectify the generation of the myriad things by yin and yang, which cannot disturb them. Ghosts and spirits cannot attest to their truth—such is their achievement.

*Zhenghe*: The spirit is that which subtly brings forth the myriad things. Embodying the spirit’s subtlety and transcending form and calculation, one can overcome things without burden. Inhaling wind and drinking dew, eating no grain, one is not intent on nourishment. The heart like a deep spring, the form like a maiden—one is tranquil and undivided. Showing no partiality or attachment, immortals and sages serve as ministers; showing no fear or anger, the sincere and guileless serve them—thus one moves in harmony with the Dao. Such a one acts with ease and non-action, and yin and yang are harmonious and still; the multitude of beings is unharmed. Thus they do not bestow or favor, do not hoard or accumulate. Yin and yang are harmonious, the four seasons are in order, nurturing is timely, grains are abundant, people know no premature death or misfortune, things know no blemish or plague, and ghosts know no supernatural manifestations. This is how the sage subtly completes the myriad things without omission.

Fan said: The spirit is that which subtly brings forth the myriad things. The myriad things are at the end of the Dao. Those who embody the spirit dwell above the myriad things, seeing nothing in them that could disturb their heart—thus they overcome things without burden. If not a divine person, who could dwell on Mount Liegu? Inhaling wind and drinking dew, eating no grain, they are not intent on nourishment. The heart like a deep spring is still and reverent, not flowing; the form like a maiden is soft and compliant, without resistance.

chunks.original_text: 不偎不爱，则非作好以亲也，而仙圣实为之制； 不畏不怒，则非作恶，以疏也，而愿悫实为之役，於物无所与也； 不施惠，而物咸自裕，於己无所取也； 不聚敛，而己无不足。 道足以役阴阳，则阴阳常调，而无谬戾之灾。 道足以旁日月，则日月常明，而无昏蚀之变。 以道运数，则有以若四时。 以道运气，则有以均风雨，夫然故未尝合六气之靖。 以育群生也，而字育常时，未尝取天地之精。 以佐五谷也，而年谷常丰，土无札伤。 得以乐其生，人无夭恶，得以终其命。 以物则遂性也，无疵疠之苦。 以鬼则不神也，无灵响之出。 是道也，非天下之至神孰能与於此？ 列子师老商氏，友伯高子，进二子之道，乘风而归。 《庄子》云：列子御风而行，泠然善，旬五日而后反。 盖神人，御寇称之也。 卢曰：夫神之滞於有，则百骸俱碍； 神之契乎真，则五根俱通也。 有通则无远不鉴，无碍则乘风而行。 被羽服以往来，托鳞毛以腾跃者，故为常理也。 非谓其尚奇也，而此寓言者也。 政和：经曰：善行无辙迹。 御风而行，虽无辙迹之可见，然犹有所待也。 惟神也，不行而至。 尹生闻之，从列子居，数月不省舍。 因问请靳其术者，十反而十不告。 尹生怼而请辞，列子又不命。 尹生退。 数月，意不已，又往从之。 列子曰：汝何去来之频？ 尹生曰：曩章戴有请於子，章义，尹生之名。 子不我告，固有憾於子。 今复脱然，是以又来。 列子曰：曩吾以汝为达，曩者，昔也。 今汝之鄙至此乎？ 姬，将告汝姬，居也。 所学於夫子者矣。 政和：三问而不答，十反而不告，道固不可言也。 卒於告之者，亦告其所学於夫子者而已。 范曰：道无问，问无应。 故古之人有三问而三不知，四问而四不答者。 尹生之於列子，十反不告，岂不欲其因心会道而默识之故耶？ 彼且有憾，至於怼而请辞，何其鄙之若是也。 故列子不得已而告之以所学之道，如不云所云。 卢曰； 昔汝去也，吾将谓汝达吾道，今汝之息憾而来，知汝之鄙陋矣。 自吾之事夫子友若人也。 夫子谓老商，若人谓伯高。 三年之后，心不敢念是非，口不敢言利害，始得夫子一眄而已。 实怀利害而不敢言，此匿怨藏情者也，故眄之而已。 卢曰：专一而不离恭敬，以至求顾吾之形，观吾之行者也。 五年之后，心庚念是非，口庚言利害，庚，当作更。 夫子始一解颜而笑。 是非利害，世间之常理，任心之所念，任口之所言，而无矜吝於胸怀，内外如一，不犹踰於匿而不显哉？ 欣其一玫，聊寄笑焉。 卢曰：三年之后，专於定也，顾眄而已。 五年之后，越於专，其哂明矣。 七年之后，从心之所念，庚无是非，从口之所言，庚无利害，夫子始一引吾并席而坐。 夫心者何？ 寂然而无意想也；
chunks.translated_text:
Neither clinging nor coveting, they do not cultivate favor to draw near, yet immortals and sages truly establish this as their rule. Neither fearing nor resenting, they do not commit wrongs to estrange, yet the sincere and guileless truly serve as their instruments—detached from all things. They bestow no favors, yet all things naturally prosper; they take nothing for themselves. The Dao suffices to command yin and yang, so yin and yang remain harmonious, free from calamities of disorder. The Dao suffices to assist the sun and moon, so sun and moon remain luminous, free from eclipses or dimming. Moving the numbers with the Dao, one accords with the four seasons. Moving the qi with the Dao, one equalizes wind and rain. Thus, they never disrupt the tranquility of the six qi in nurturing all living beings, yet their nurturing is always timely. They never seize the essence of heaven and earth to aid the five grains, yet the harvests are always abundant, and the soil suffers no blight. People delight in their lives, knowing no premature death or misfortune, and fulfill their destinies. Things attain their natures, free from plague or blemish. Ghosts lose their numinosity, emitting no supernatural manifestations. This is the Dao—who but the most divine under heaven could partake in this?

Liezi studied under Master Lao Shang and befriended Bo Gaozi, advancing in the Way of these two masters until he could ride the wind and return. *Zhuangzi* says: Liezi traveled by riding the wind, soaring lightly and gracefully, returning after fifteen days. This is how the divine person, Yu Kou, described him.

Lu said: When the spirit is mired in being, the hundred limbs are all obstructed; when the spirit accords with the true, the five senses are all unobstructed. With unobstructedness, nothing is too distant to perceive; with no impediments, one rides the wind and travels. Those who don feathered robes to come and go, or entrust themselves to scales and fur to leap and bound, do so as a matter of constant principle—not because they prize the extraordinary, but because this is the meaning of their allegory.

*Zhenghe* says: The Classic states: "The good traveler leaves no tracks." Though riding the wind leaves no visible trace, it still depends on something. Only the spirit arrives without moving.

Yin Sheng, having heard of this, went to live with Liezi. For months, he did not return home. He then asked repeatedly to be taught the art, but after ten requests, Liezi refused ten times. Yin Sheng grew resentful and asked to leave, but Liezi gave no command. Yin Sheng withdrew. Months later, his resolve unbroken, he returned again. Liezi said: "Why do you come and go so frequently?"

Yin Sheng replied: "Formerly, Zhang Dai (Yin Sheng’s courtesy name) made a request of you, but you did not grant it, so I harbored resentment. Now, my heart is suddenly at ease, so I have come again."

Liezi said: "Before, I took you for one who understood. Now, do you show such vulgarity? Ji, I will tell you what I learned from my master."

*Zhenghe* says: Three questions met with no answer; ten requests met with no teaching—the Dao cannot truly be spoken. In the end, he told him only what he had learned from his master.

Fan said: The Dao does not answer questions; questions receive no response. Thus, the ancients had those who asked three times and received three "I do not know"s, or four times and four refusals. With Yin Sheng and Liezi, ten requests went unanswered—was this not because he wished him to grasp the Dao through his own heart and silently comprehend it? Yet he grew resentful, even indignant enough to ask to leave—how could his vulgarity be so great? Thus, Liezi had no choice but to tell him what he had learned, as if speaking without speaking.

Lu said: When you left before, I thought you had grasped my Way. Now, seeing you return to assuage your resentment, I know your shallowness.

Since I began serving my master (referring to Lao Shang) and befriending such a one (referring to Bo Gaozi), after three years, my heart dared not entertain thoughts of right or wrong, my mouth dared not speak of profit or harm—only then did my master deign to glance at me once. Truly harboring profit and harm yet not daring to speak is to conceal resentment and hide one’s feelings, so he merely glanced.

Lu said: Devoted and unwavering in reverence, one seeks only to observe my form and study my conduct.

After five years, my heart *geng*-thought of right and wrong, my mouth *geng*-spoke of profit and harm (*geng* should read *geng*, "again"). Only then did my master relax his expression and smile. Right and wrong, profit and harm are the common principles of the world—letting the heart think as it will, the mouth speak as it will, without arrogance or stinginess in the breast, inner and outer as one—is this not far beyond concealing and not revealing? Delighted by this restraint, he smiled in passing.

Lu said: After three years, devoted to stillness, he merely glanced. After five years, transcending devotion, his smile became clear.

After seven years, following the heart’s thoughts, *geng* without right or wrong; following the mouth’s words, *geng* without profit or harm—only then did my master draw me to sit beside him on the same mat. What is the heart? It is stillness without intention or thought.

Those who embody the spirit dwell above the myriad things, seeing nothing in them that could disturb their heart—thus they overcome things without burden. If not a divine person, who could dwell on Mount Liegu? Inhaling wind and drinking dew, eating no grain, they are not intent on nourishment. The heart like a deep spring is still and reverent, not flowing; the form like a maiden is soft and compliant, without resistance.

chunks.original_text: 口者何？ 默然而自吐纳也。 若顺心之极，则无是非； 任口之理，则无利害。 道契师友，同位比肩，故其宜耳。 卢曰：审之而后言欲是非利害，无所误也。 九年之后，横心之所念，横口之所言，亦不知我之是非利害欤，亦不知彼之是非利害欤，亦不知夫子之为我师，若人之为我友，内外进矣。 心既无念，口既无违，故能恣其所念，纵其所言，体道穷宗，为世津梁。 终日念而非我念，终日言而非我言，若以无念为念，无言为言，未造於极也。 所谓无为而无不为者如斯，则彼此之异，於何而求？ 师资之义，将何所施？ 故曰内外尽矣。 卢曰：都无心，故是非利害不择之而后言纵横者也。 纵心而言，皆合斯道。 范曰：是非之彰，道之所以亏矣； 利害之生，情伪之所以感也。 列子之学，三年之后，心不敢念是非，则心有所择而念； 口不言利害，则口有所择而言。 故始得夫子一眄而已，则道存於目击之间也。 五年之后，心庚念是非，则心无所择矣，由未能泯是非也； 口庚言利害，则口无择矣。 由未能忘利害也。 故夫子始一解颜而笑。 则心冥於莫逆之际也。 七年之后，纵心之所念，庚无是非，则是非泯矣，由未能至於无念； 纵口之所言，庚无利害，则利害忘矣，由未能至於忘言。 故夫子始引吾并席而坐，则意会於交臂之间也。 横心之所念，则出念不念，而念出於不念矣； 横口之所言，则出言不言，而言出於不言矣。 孰是孰非，孰利孰害，彼我两忘，而俱化於道，又乌知夫子之为我师，若人之为我友？ 数始於一参，中於五，屈於七，究於九。 古之学道者，或九日而后能外生，或九传而后得於疑始，或九年而大妙，盖以入道之序，至是而终，进於无数故也。 而后眼如耳，耳如鼻，鼻如口，无不同也。 卢曰：眼、耳、口、鼻，不用其所能，各任之而无心，故云无不同耳。 心凝形释，骨肉都融，不觉形之所倚，足之所履，随风东西，犹木叶干壳。 竟不知风乘我邪，我乘风乎？ 夫眼、耳、鼻、口，各有攸司。 令神凝形废，无待於外，则视听不资眼目，臭味不赖鼻口，故六藏七孔，四肢百节，块然尸居，同为一物，则形奚所倚，足奚所履，我之乘风，风之乘我，孰能辩也。 卢曰：神凝者，不动也。 形释者，无碍也。 骨肉都融者，忘形骸也。 形骸忘於所之，神念离於所着，则与风气同之上下也。 政和：三年而不惑，故始夫子一眄； 五年而不蔽，故至於解颜而笑； 七年而不累，故引之并席而坐； 九年而是非利害简之而不得，则物我两忘，五官相彻，风之乘我，我之乘风，何容心焉？ 令女居先生之门，曾未浃时，而怼憾者再三。 汝之片体将气所不受，汝之一节将地所不载。 用其情，有其身，则肌骨不能相容，一体将无所寄，岂二仪之所能覆载？ 履虚乘风，其可几乎？ 尹生甚作，屏息良久，不敢复言。 卢曰：列子所以乘风者，为能忘其身也。 《老子》曰：吾所以有大患者，为吾有身。 及吾无身，吾有何患也？ 若其形骸之不忘，则一节之重则地所不能载，何暇乘风而凌虚哉？ 政和：致道者忘心，况於怼憾者乎？ 片体气所不受，一节地所不载，则汝身将非汝有也，何得有夫道？ 范曰：六彻相因，则物物皆通； 六凿相攘，则物物皆碍。
chunks.translated_text:
What is the mouth? It is silence that naturally inhales and exhales. If one follows the heart’s utmost, then there is no right or wrong; if one follows the principle of the mouth, then there is no profit or harm. When the Dao harmonizes with master and friend, standing side by side in the same position, this is fitting.

Lu said: Examine carefully before speaking to ensure right and wrong, profit and harm do not lead one astray. After nine years, whether the heart’s thoughts are unrestrained or the mouth’s words are unchecked, one no longer knows one’s own right or wrong, profit or harm, nor that of others; one no longer knows the master as one’s teacher or others as one’s friends—inner and outer have advanced. Since the heart has no thoughts and the mouth no contradictions, one may indulge in thoughts and give free rein to speech, embodying the Dao and exhausting its essence, becoming a bridge for the world. Though one thinks all day, it is not one’s own thought; though one speaks all day, it is not one’s own speech. If one takes non-thought as thought and non-speech as speech, one has not yet reached the ultimate. The saying “non-action yet nothing is left undone” is like this—where then can one seek the difference between self and other? Where can the relationship between teacher and disciple be applied? Thus it is said: inner and outer are complete.

Lu said: With no heart at all, right and wrong, profit and harm are not chosen before speaking—words flow freely. When the heart is unrestrained and speech follows, all accords with this Dao.

Fan said: The manifestation of right and wrong is how the Dao becomes deficient; the arising of profit and harm is how emotions and falsity become entangled. In Liezi’s study, after three years, the heart dared not think of right or wrong, yet the heart still chose what to think; the mouth did not speak of profit or harm, yet the mouth still chose what to say. Thus, he merely received a glance from the master—yet the Dao resided in that instant of eye contact. After five years, the heart *geng* thought of right and wrong, so the heart no longer chose, though it had not yet dissolved right and wrong; the mouth *geng* spoke of profit and harm, so the mouth no longer selected, though it had not yet forgotten profit and harm. Thus, the master first relaxed his expression and smiled—his heart was in perfect accord. After seven years, following the heart’s unrestrained thoughts, *geng* without right or wrong, right and wrong were dissolved, though one had not yet reached non-thought; following the mouth’s unchecked speech, *geng* without profit or harm, profit and harm were forgotten, though one had not yet reached non-speech. Thus, the master first drew him to sit beside him on the same mat—understanding passed between them in an instant. When the heart’s thoughts are unrestrained, thought arises from non-thought; when the mouth’s speech is unchecked, speech arises from non-speech. Who is right, who is wrong? What is profit, what is harm? Self and other are both forgotten, merging into the Dao—how then could one know the master as one’s teacher or others as one’s friends?

The sequence begins with one, progresses through five, culminates at seven, and reaches completion at nine. Those who studied the Dao in ancient times: some attained mastery over life after nine days, some resolved their doubts after nine transmissions, some achieved great subtlety after nine years. This is because the order of entering the Dao reaches its end here, advancing into the realm beyond calculation. Thereafter, the eye is like the ear, the ear like the nose, the nose like the mouth—all are the same.

Lu said: The eye, ear, mouth, and nose do not employ their usual functions; each is entrusted without the heart’s involvement—thus it is said they are no different.

The heart congeals, the form dissolves, bones and flesh completely fuse. One does not sense the body’s support or the feet’s tread, drifting east and west with the wind like a dry leaf or husk. Does the wind ride me, or do I ride the wind? The eye, ear, nose, and mouth each have their appointed roles. When spirit congeals and form is abandoned, with no reliance on externals, then sight and hearing do not depend on the eyes and ears, scents and tastes do not rely on the nose and mouth. Thus, the six viscera and seven orifices, the four limbs and hundred joints, sit inert as a corpse, all becoming one thing. Where then does the body lean? Where do the feet tread? Whether I ride the wind or the wind rides me—who can distinguish?

Lu said: When spirit congeals, it does not move. When form dissolves, it is without obstruction. When bones and flesh completely fuse, one forgets the physical frame. Forgetting the frame’s destination, the spirit’s thoughts detach from attachment—then one rises and falls with the wind and air.

*Zhenghe* says: After three years, one is no longer deluded, so the master first glanced. After five years, one is no longer obscured, so he relaxed his expression and smiled. After seven years, one is no longer burdened, so he drew him to sit beside him on the same mat. After nine years, right and wrong, profit and harm cannot be distinguished—self and other are both forgotten, the five senses interpenetrate, the wind rides me, I ride the wind—where is there room for the heart’s involvement?

If you dwell in the master’s gate but have not yet passed a full cycle of time, yet resentment and grievance arise again and again—your single limb will not be borne by qi, your single joint will not be supported by the earth. Employing emotion and possessing a body, flesh and bone cannot coexist; the whole being will have nowhere to reside—how could heaven and earth cover and bear it? How could one approach riding the void and mounting the wind?

Yin was greatly alarmed, held his breath for a long while, and dared not speak again.

Lu said: Liezi could ride the wind because he forgot his body. *Laozi* says: “The reason I have great trouble is that I have a body. If I no longer had a body, what trouble would I have?” If one does not forget the physical frame, then the weight of a single joint is more than the earth can bear—how could one have leisure to ride the wind and soar through the void?

*Zhenghe* says: Those who attain the Dao forget the heart—how much more should they forget resentment and grievance? If a single limb is not borne by qi and a single joint is not supported by the earth, then your body will no longer be yours—how could you possess the Dao?

Fan said: When the six senses interpenetrate, all things communicate; when the six apertures conflict, all things are obstructed.
